intro: Pulsatilla alpina, commonly known as the alpine pasqueflower, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the Ranunculaceae family and is characterized by its showy, cup-shaped flowers that range in color from white to pale yellow. The plant typically grows in alpine meadows and rocky slopes, thriving in cold, dry environments. Its leaves are palmately divided, and it produces a distinctive, milky sap that contains toxic compounds. Pulsatilla alpina is also known for its early spring blooming habit, often one of the first flowers to appear after snowmelt.
